question:
In which of the following states is shifting agriculture locally called Penda ?

SSC MTS 17/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Shifting agriculture is a traditional method where land is cleared (usually by slashing and burning), cultivated for a few years, and then left fallow.
  • In Andhra Pradesh, this practice is locally known as “Penda”.
  • It is commonly practiced in tribal and forested regions of the state.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Orissa – Called Podu.
  • (c) West Bengal – Known as Jhum cultivation.
  • (d) Madhya Pradesh – Known as Bewar or Dahiya.

Additional Information:

  • Practiced mainly in hilly and tribal regions.
  • If repeated without recovery time, it leads to soil degradation.
  • Also found in parts of Northeast, Central, and Southern India.

question:
The term 'Aus', 'Aman' and 'Boro' are associated with which crop in India?

SSC MTS 17/10/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The terms ‘Aus’, ‘Aman’, and ‘Boro’ refer to the three cropping seasons of paddy (rice) cultivation in India, particularly in eastern states like West Bengal, Assam, and Odisha.
  • These are seasonal varieties of paddy grown based on rainfall pattern and temperature:

Aus – Sown in summer and harvested before monsoon (April–July)

Aman – Sown during monsoon and harvested in winter (July–December)

Boro – Sown in winter and harvested in spring (November–April)

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Maize, (b) Wheat, and (c) Jute are not classified by these three seasonal names.
  • These terms are exclusively linked to rice cultivation.

Additional Information:

  • Boro rice requires irrigation as it is grown in dry season.
  • Aman is the main crop in terms of area and production.
  • These classifications help in regional planning and improving yield through seasonal variety adaptation.

question:
Which type of tea in large amount is exported from India to importing countries?

SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• India is one of the largest producers and exporters of black tea in the world.
  • Black tea undergoes full oxidation, which gives it a strong flavor and longer shelf life, making it suitable for international trade.
  • It is highly demanded in countries like Russia, the UK, Iran, and the UAE.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Herbal tea – Mostly consumed domestically or exported in small niche segments.
  • (b) Regular tea – Not a specific type; may refer to black or mixed blends.
  • (c) Green tea – Exported in smaller volumes compared to black tea.

Additional Information:

  • Major black tea exporting regions in India include Assam, Darjeeling, and Nilgiris.
  • India exports tea through ports like Kolkata, Kochi, and Mumbai.
  • Tea Board of India regulates and promotes tea exports from the country.

question:
The people of Himachal Pradesh make channels to bring water from a glacier or rainwater to villages for the function of mainly irrigation. These channels are locally known as:

SSC MTS 28/10/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In Himachal Pradesh, people build traditional irrigation channels to bring water from glaciers or rainwater sources to their villages, especially for irrigation in hilly terrain.
  • These channels are locally known as “Guls” or “Kuls”.
  • They are often maintained by community efforts and play a vital role in water conservation in mountain regions.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Khadins – Found in Rajasthan; used for harvesting rainwater.
  • (c) Johads – Small earthen check dams in Rajasthan and Haryana used for water recharge.
  • (d) Baori – Stepwells mainly found in Gujarat and Rajasthan for water storage.

Additional Information:

  • Guls/Kuls are centuries-old systems and are part of indigenous water management practices.
  • Water from these channels is often diverted to fields using wooden or stone outlets.
  • These systems are eco-friendly and rely on gravity for water flow.

question:
Which of the following states is the biggest producer of Pulses?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Madhya Pradesh is the largest producer of pulses in India, contributing over 25% of the country’s total pulse production.
  • The state’s climate and soil conditions are highly suitable for pulse crops such as gram (chana), lentil (masoor), pigeon pea (arhar), and urad/moong.
  • Pulses are mainly grown in Rabi and Kharif seasons, with gram being the dominant crop.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Haryana, (c) Punjab, and (d) Bihar produce pulses in relatively lower quantities and focus more on wheat, rice, and sugarcane.

Additional Information:

  • India is the largest producer and consumer of pulses in the world, but still imports due to high demand.
  • Other major pulse-producing states include Rajasthan, Maharashtra, and Uttar Pradesh.
  • Pulses play a key role in nitrogen fixation and improving soil fertility.

question:
Which of the following statements correctly defines the green revolution?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_1: It is a new strategy in agriculture to produce food grains, especially wheat and rice.
option_2: It is a new strategy to increase the share of the forest.
option_3: It is a new strategy to use green colour for all purposes.
option_4: It is a new strategy to use only herbal products.
solution:
• The Green Revolution refers to a period during the 1960s and 70s in India when modern agricultural techniques were introduced to increase food grain production, especially wheat and rice.
  • It involved the use of high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds, chemical fertilizers, irrigation, and mechanization.
  • It led to self-sufficiency in food production and reduced dependence on food imports.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Increasing forest share – Not related to the Green Revolution.
  • (c) Use of green colour – Irrelevant.
  • (d) Use of herbal products – Has no link to food grain production or agricultural revolution.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution was initiated under the guidance of M.S. Swaminathan, known as the Father of Green Revolution in India.
  • Punjab, Haryana, and western Uttar Pradesh were the leading states in Green Revolution implementation.
  • While it increased production, it also led to issues like soil degradation, groundwater depletion, and regional imbalance.

question:
According to the Agricultural and Processed food Development products Authority Export (APEDA) 2020-2021, which state of India has the first rank in grapes production?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• According to the Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority (APEDA) report for 2020–21, Maharashtra holds the top position in grape production in India.
  • The state contributes over 67% of the country's total grape production, making it the largest producer by a significant margin.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Karnataka – While Karnataka is the second-largest grape producer, its contribution is considerably less than that of Maharashtra.
  • (c) Bihar – Not a major grape-producing state; it focuses more on crops like litchi and makhana.
  • (d) Uttar Pradesh – Primarily known for sugarcane and wheat production, not grapes.

Additional Information:

  • Nashik district in Maharashtra is renowned as the "Grape Capital of India" due to its extensive grape cultivation and export activities.
  • Maharashtra's favorable climate and soil conditions contribute to its dominance in grape production.
  • The state also leads in grape exports, with major destinations including the Netherlands, the UK, and the UAE.

question:
The green revolution technology resulted in an increase in production of cereal production from 72.4 million tons in 1965-66 to ________ million tons in 1978-79.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Green Revolution technology, introduced in India during the mid-1960s, focused on high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds, chemical fertilizers, irrigation, and modern farming techniques.
  • As a result, cereal production in India **increased from 72.4 million tons in 1965–66 to ** 9 million tons in 1978–79.
  • This dramatic growth marked a turning point in Indian agriculture, helping to achieve self-sufficiency in food grains.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) 150.8, (b) 165.9, and (d) 141.2 are either exaggerated or not aligned with the official agricultural statistics of 1978–79.
  • 131.9 million tons is the correct figure based on government data from that period.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution primarily benefited Punjab, Haryana, and western Uttar Pradesh.
  • It focused mostly on wheat and rice.
  • While it improved food security, it also led to ecological and social issues like soil degradation, regional disparity, and overuse of groundwater.

question:
The headquarters of the second Green Revolution cell was in ________.

SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Second Green Revolution Cell was established to promote agricultural development, particularly in the eastern region of India, which was not significantly impacted by the first Green Revolution.
  • Its headquarters was set up in Patna, Bihar, to coordinate and implement strategies for improving rice productivity, irrigation, and modern techniques in eastern states.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Raipur, (c) Kolkata, and (d) Bhubaneswar are important cities in agriculture but were not chosen as the HQ for the second Green Revolution cell.
  • Patna was selected due to its central location in the targeted eastern region and high potential for agricultural growth.

Additional Information:

  • The Second Green Revolution aimed to increase productivity in eastern India, including states like Bihar, West Bengal, Odisha, Chhattisgarh, and Eastern UP.
  • It emphasized better irrigation, technology adoption, and farmer education.
  • The initiative was supported by institutions like the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) and the Ministry of Agriculture.

question:
Which of the following statements about the aims of National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA) of India is/are correct?

To make agriculture more productive.

2. To make agriculture more sustainable.

3. To promote organic farming.

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_2: Only 2 and 3 are correct.
option_4: Only 1 and 2 are correct.
solution:
• The National Mission for Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA), launched under the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC), aims to make Indian agriculture more productive, sustainable, and climate-resilient.
  • The mission promotes location-specific Integrated/Composite Farming Systems, soil health management, efficient water use, and organic farming practices.
  • Therefore, all three statements are correct:
    1. To make agriculture more productive.
    2. To make agriculture more sustainable.
    3. To promote organic farming.

Answer: (c) 1, 2 and 3 are correct.

Additional Information:

  • NMSA focuses on enhancing agricultural productivity, especially in rainfed areas, through integrated farming systems.
  • It emphasizes the adoption of sustainable practices like soil health management, efficient water use, and organic farming to ensure long-term agricultural sustainability.
  • The mission also aims to build capacity among farmers and stakeholders for climate change adaptation and mitigation.

question:
What was a significant negative environmental impact of the Green Revolution?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
option_3: Increase in air pollution
solution:
• One of the most significant negative environmental impacts of the Green Revolution was soil degradation.
  • The extensive use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, and intensive monocropping led to the loss of soil fertility and nutrient imbalance over time.
  • Over-irrigation also caused waterlogging and salinization, further degrading agricultural land.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Deforestation – Not directly linked to Green Revolution practices.
  • (c) Increase in air pollution – Was not a central outcome of Green Revolution techniques.
  • (d) Ozone layer depletion – Caused by CFCs, unrelated to agricultural practices of the Green Revolution.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution began in the 1960s, primarily focusing on wheat and rice production.
  • Though it helped India achieve food self-sufficiency, it led to issues like groundwater depletion, loss of biodiversity, and dependency on chemicals.
  • States like Punjab and Haryana, which were at the forefront, experienced the most ecological stress.

question:
How was the growth in all food grains after the Green Revolution?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The growth in all food grains after the Green Revolution was disproportionate.
  • The revolution primarily focused on wheat and rice, leading to a massive increase in their production, especially in states like Punjab, Haryana, and Western UP.
  • However, coarse cereals, pulses, and oilseeds did not see a similar rate of growth, resulting in regional and crop-wise imbalance.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Unitary – Implies equal growth, which didn’t happen across all crops.
  • (b) Proportionate – The growth was not uniform across all food grains.
  • (c) Unpredictable – The growth was largely predictable in wheat and rice due to targeted efforts.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution (1960s–1980s) led to India becoming self-sufficient in food grain production.
  • It increased productivity in select regions but neglected rain-fed areas and diverse crops.
  • The imbalance also contributed to nutritional deficiency and ecological issues in non-priority regions.

question:
What was the main objective of the Second Green Revolution in India?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Ensuring food security in the western states
option_2: Promoting conventional agricultural practices
option_3: Focusing on holistic development in agriculture
option_4: Increasing the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides
solution:
• The main objective of the Second Green Revolution in India was to bring holistic development in agriculture, especially in areas left out during the first Green Revolution.
  • It aimed at improving productivity, sustainability, farmer income, and resource efficiency across diverse agro-climatic regions.
  • The approach included balanced fertilizer use, micro-irrigation, soil health improvement, organic farming, and market linkages.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Ensuring food security in the western states – The western region already benefited from the first Green Revolution.
  • (b) Promoting conventional agricultural practices – The Second Green Revolution emphasized modern and sustainable practices, not traditional ones.
  • (d) Increasing the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides – It promoted balanced and reduced usage, not increased reliance.

Additional Information:

  • The Second Green Revolution was focused on the eastern and rain-fed states such as Bihar, Odisha, West Bengal, Chhattisgarh, Jharkhand, and eastern Uttar Pradesh.
  • It aligned with programs like National Food Security Mission (NFSM) and Soil Health Card Scheme.
  • The goal was inclusive growth by integrating technology, infrastructure, and institutional support.

question:
Which of the following movements created regional disparities between large and small farmers in India?

SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Green Revolution in India, while boosting food grain production (especially wheat and rice), also led to regional and social disparities.
  • Large farmers in well-irrigated states like Punjab, Haryana, and Western UP greatly benefited from the use of HYV seeds, chemical fertilizers, and mechanization.
  • Small and marginal farmers, especially in rain-fed and backward regions, lacked access to such resources, leading to economic inequality and regional imbalance.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (b) Yellow Revolution – Related to oilseed production, had limited regional impact.
  • (c) Pink Revolution – Associated with meat and poultry production, did not cause notable rural disparities.
  • (d) Blue Revolution – Focused on fisheries and aquaculture, and was more sectoral than regional.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution increased production but also led to problems like soil degradation, overuse of water, and ecological stress.
  • The government later launched missions like the Second Green Revolution to address these imbalances and extend benefits to eastern and tribal regions.
  • This disparity has been a subject of rural sociology and agrarian policy debates.

question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct?

i. The first green revolution led to over-exploitation of natural resources.

ii. The second Green Revolution was more focused on Southern India.

iii. The second green revolution ensured in achieving sustainable livelihood security.

SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Statement i – Correct:

    The first Green Revolution led to an excessive use of chemical fertilizers, groundwater, and pesticides, especially in regions like Punjab and Haryana. This caused over-exploitation of natural resources, leading to soil degradation, water table depletion, and environmental imbalance.

  • Statement ii – Incorrect:

    The Second Green Revolution was not focused on Southern India. It mainly targeted Eastern India, especially the states of Bihar, West Bengal, Odisha, Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, and eastern Uttar Pradesh, to reduce regional disparities.

  • Statement iii – Correct:

    The Second Green Revolution aimed to ensure sustainable livelihood security by promoting balanced fertilizer use, improved irrigation, organic farming, and climate-resilient practices, focusing on long-term sustainability.

Answer: (a) i and iii

Additional Information:

  • The first Green Revolution increased food grain production but benefited only select regions and crops, creating social and ecological challenges.
  • The second Green Revolution took a more inclusive and sustainable approach, integrating technology, extension services, and support for small and marginal farmers.

question:
What action was taken by the government to celebrate the achievement of the Green Revolution in agriculture?

SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: Released a regular salary for the farmers
option_2: Distributed free food to all the people
option_3: Released a special stamp, ‘Wheat Revolution’
option_4: Distributed green vegetables to the people
solution:
• To commemorate the success of the Green Revolution, the Government of India released a special postal stamp titled “Wheat Revolution”.
  • This was done to acknowledge the dramatic increase in wheat production due to the adoption of high-yielding variety (HYV) seeds, fertilizers, irrigation, and scientific farming practices.
  • The term "Wheat Revolution" is closely associated with the achievements of the Green Revolution, especially in Punjab, Haryana, and Western Uttar Pradesh.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Regular salary for farmers – No such nationwide provision was introduced.
  • (b) Free food distribution to all people – Not part of Green Revolution celebrations.
  • (d) Distribution of green vegetables – Unrelated to the celebration or recognition of the revolution.

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution began in the 1960s under the guidance of scientists like M.S. Swaminathan.
  • It made India self-sufficient in food grain production, especially in wheat and rice.
  • The success of wheat production led to symbolic recognition through the postal stamp in 1968.

question:
What is the economic justification for subsidies in the agriculture sector?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: It is mostly used to provide benefits for rich farmers.
option_2: It is a part of government expenditure in the service sector.
option_3: It is an incentive to provide the benefits of advanced technology and decrease the cost of production.
option_4: It is used to provide benefits for capital goods producers in agriculture.
solution:
• The economic justification for subsidies in the agriculture sector is to act as an incentive that enables farmers to adopt advanced technology, such as high-yielding seeds, fertilizers, machinery, and irrigation systems.
  • This support lowers the cost of production, especially for small and marginal farmers, making farming more profitable and sustainable.
  • Subsidies also help in ensuring food security and price stability.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Benefits for rich farmers – Subsidies aim to assist resource-poor farmers, though misuse can occur.
  • (b) Service sector expenditure – Agriculture falls under the primary sector, not service sector.
  • (d) Capital goods producers – The main target is farmers, not manufacturers of agricultural machinery.

Additional Information:

  • Common agricultural subsidies include support for fertilizers, electricity, irrigation, crop insurance, and MSP (Minimum Support Price).
  • They are essential for promoting inclusive rural development and bridging the gap between urban and rural economies.
  • However, rationalization of subsidies is recommended to avoid overuse and environmental damage.

question:
In West Bengal, how many rice crops are grown in a year?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• In West Bengal, farmers cultivate three rice crops annually: Aus, Aman, and Boro.
  • These crops are grown in different seasons, leveraging the state's favorable climatic conditions and irrigation facilities.

Additional Information:

  • Aus: Sown in summer (March–April) and harvested in autumn (July–August).
  • Aman: Sown during the monsoon (June–July) and harvested in winter (November–December).
  • Boro: Sown in winter (November–December) and harvested in spring (April–May), requiring assured irrigation.
  • This tri-seasonal cultivation contributes to West Bengal's position as India's leading rice-producing state, with an annual production of approximately 15 million metric tons .

question:
Which state in India was the most transformed by the Green Revolution?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The state that was most transformed by the Green Revolution in India was Punjab.
  • It became the epicenter of the Green Revolution during the 1960s and 1970s due to:
    • Availability of irrigation facilities (especially from Bhakra-Nangal Dam)
    • High adoption of HYV (High-Yielding Variety) seeds
    • Extensive use of fertilizers and pesticides
    • Mechanization and strong government support
  • As a result, Punjab saw a massive increase in wheat and rice production, leading to prosperity among large farmers and making the state India's “Granary of India”.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Kerala – Focused more on plantation crops; not impacted significantly by the Green Revolution.
  • (b) Maharashtra – Saw some agricultural improvements, but not due to the core Green Revolution model.
  • (c) West Bengal – Benefited during later stages, especially from Boro rice, but not to the extent of Punjab.

Additional Information:

  • The success of the Green Revolution in Punjab inspired similar efforts in Haryana and Western Uttar Pradesh.
  • However, it also led to long-term issues like soil depletion, groundwater crisis, and decline in crop diversity.

question:
In the given main characteristics of farming which is NOT a characteristic of the Indian commercial farming?

SSC CHSL 01/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_4: High yielding variety seeds
solution:
• The option (a) Slash and burn is NOT a characteristic of Indian commercial farming.
  • Slash and burn refers to a form of primitive subsistence farming, commonly practiced in tribal and forested regions. It involves clearing forest land by cutting and burning trees and then cultivating the land temporarily.
  • Indian commercial farming, on the other hand, involves:
    • Use of High-Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds
    • Application of chemical fertilizers
    • Use of pesticides and insecticides
    • Focus on cash crops like sugarcane, cotton, and wheat for market sale

Why other options are correct for commercial farming:

  • (b) Insecticides and pesticides – Used to protect high-value crops
  • (c) Chemical fertilisers – Used to boost productivity
  • (d) High yielding variety seeds – Essential for commercial output and profit

Additional Information:

  • Slash and burn is known by different names in India, like Jhum in the Northeast, Podu in Odisha, and Bewar in Madhya Pradesh.
  • Commercial farming is practiced in states like Punjab, Haryana, Maharashtra, and involves large-scale, market-oriented agriculture.

question:
Which of the following types of crops are sown after the end of the monsoon season?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Rabi crops are sown after the end of the monsoon season, typically from October to December, and harvested in March to April.
  • These crops require cooler climates for growth and less water compared to Kharif crops.
  • Examples of Rabi crops include wheat, barley, mustard, peas, and gram.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Kharif crops – Sown at the beginning of monsoon (June–July) and harvested in September–October.
  • (b) Zaid crops – Grown in the short summer season between Rabi and Kharif (April–June), such as watermelon, cucumber.
  • (d) Vital crops – This is not a recognized category in agricultural terminology.

Additional Information:

  • Rabi crops benefit from residual soil moisture after the monsoon.
  • India’s major Rabi-producing states include Punjab, Haryana, Uttar Pradesh, and Madhya Pradesh.
  • Irrigation is often required as these crops are grown in the dry winter season.

question:
Which of the following is NOT one of the consequences of the Green Revolution?

SSC CHSL 02/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Employment of agricultural workers increased
option_2: Rising prices and a shift in the mode of payment of agricultural workers from payment in cash to payment in kind (grain)
option_3: Wages of agricultural workers increased
option_4: The rich grew richer and many of the poor stagnated or grew poorer
solution:
• The Green Revolution led to significant changes in Indian agriculture, such as increased food grain production, mechanization, and use of modern inputs.
  • However, one thing it did not cause was a shift in payment from cash to kind (grain). In fact, with increasing commercialization, the mode of payment moved more towards cash, not the other way around.

Why other options are correct consequences:

  • (a) Employment of agricultural workers increased – More intensive farming and double cropping created seasonal labor demand.
  • (c) Wages of agricultural workers increased – Due to higher productivity and demand for skilled labor.
  • (d) The rich grew richer and the poor stagnated or grew poorer – Large farmers benefited from access to inputs, while small and marginal farmers often couldn't afford them, increasing inequality.

Answer: (b) Rising prices and a shift in the mode of payment of agricultural workers from payment in cash to payment in kind (grain)

Additional Information:

  • The Green Revolution widened economic and regional disparities, benefiting irrigated regions like Punjab, Haryana, and parts of Western UP.
  • It also led to overuse of chemical inputs, soil degradation, and reduced crop diversity.
  • Mechanization reduced labor needs in some areas but increased wage rates where labor was still required.

question:
Which of the following types of crops are sown at the beginning of the monsoon season?

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Kharif crops are sown at the beginning of the monsoon season, typically between June and July, and harvested in September to October.
  • These crops depend heavily on rainwater and are suited to the warm, wet climate of the Indian monsoon.
  • Examples include rice, maize, cotton, soybean, and bajra.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Rabi crops – Sown after the monsoon, during October–December, and harvested in spring.
  • (c) Vital crops – Not a recognized category in agriculture.
  • (d) Zaid crops – Grown in the short summer season between Rabi and Kharif, i.e., April to June.

question:
Which of the following statement/s about the Green Revolution is/are CORRECT?

i. India became self-sufficient with the introduction of the Green Revolution.

ii. The Green Revolution led to loss of nutrients in the soil from farming the same crop over and over again.

iii. The Green Revolution led to depletion of fresh ground water.

SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Only i and iii
option_2: Only i and ii
option_3: i, ii and iii
solution:
Let’s examine each statement about the Green Revolution:

  • Statement i – Correct:

    The Green Revolution made India self-sufficient in food grain production, especially wheat and rice, reducing the country’s dependence on imports and preventing famines.

  • Statement ii – Correct:

    Due to the practice of monoculture (same crop repeatedly on the same land), there was nutrient depletion in soil, as certain nutrients were continuously extracted without proper replenishment.

  • Statement iii – Correct:

    The intensive irrigation required for high-yielding crops led to over-extraction of groundwater, causing groundwater depletion, especially in Punjab, Haryana, and Western Uttar Pradesh.

All three statements are correct.

question:
Which of the following statements are true about the positive impact of the Green Revolution (GR) on yield levels in India?

i. During the post GR period, the yield of rice grew at a much faster rate than that of wheat.

ii. GR technology had penetrated more in wheat crop than in the rice crop.

iii. During post GR period, the area under rice achieved a relatively slow growth when compared to the area under wheat.

SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: Only ii and iii
option_2: Only i and iii
option_3: Only i and ii
option_4: i, ii and iii
solution:
Let’s evaluate each statement based on historical agricultural data and the impact of the Green Revolution:

  • Statement i – Incorrect:

    The yield of wheat grew at a faster rate than rice during the post-Green Revolution period.

    • The Green Revolution initially focused on wheat, especially in Punjab, Haryana, and Western UP.
    • High-Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds for wheat were more widely adopted earlier than for rice.
  • Statement ii – Correct:

    Green Revolution technology penetrated more deeply in wheat cultivation due to better irrigation, input availability, and suitable climatic conditions.

    • Wheat production saw a dramatic increase, and India became self-sufficient in wheat much before rice.
  • Statement iii – Correct:

    The area under rice expanded more slowly than wheat in the post-Green Revolution period.

    • This is partly because rice cultivation required more water and was more dependent on traditional and regional practices, slowing technological adoption.

Therefore, only statements ii and iii are correct.

question:
Which of these is NOT true of the second phase of the green revolution?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd shift)
option_1: It was adopted by farmers living in dry and semi-arid regions of India.
option_2: It was launched in areas with a significant shift from dry to wet (irrigated) cultivation.
option_3: It covered the period of the 1960s and 1970s.
option_4: It covered the period of the 1980s.
solution:
• The second phase of the Green Revolution refers to agricultural advancements that took place mainly during the 1980s, aiming to expand the benefits of the first Green Revolution to other regions and crops beyond wheat and rice.

Let’s examine the statements:

  • (a) Adopted by farmers in dry and semi-arid regions – ✅True
    • The second phase targeted underdeveloped, rain-fed, and semi-arid regions, promoting sustainable and region-specific practices.
  • (b) Launched in areas with a shift from dry to irrigated cultivation – ✅True
    • Efforts were made to improve irrigation and expand HYV seed use to areas previously dependent on rainfall.
  • (c) Covered the 1960s and 1970s – ❌Not true
    • This timeframe relates to the first phase of the Green Revolution, which focused mainly on Punjab, Haryana, and Western UP for wheat production.
  • (d) Covered the 1980s – ✅True
    • The second phase began in the 1980s, focusing on crop diversification and regional inclusion, especially in eastern and central India.

question:
Identify the crop which is grown in Kharif cropping season in Northern States of India.

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)
solution:
• Rice is the major Kharif crop grown in Northern states of India, such as Punjab, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, and Haryana, during the monsoon season (June–October).
  • It requires hot and humid climate and plenty of water, which is naturally provided during the Kharif season.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Mustard – Grown in Rabi season (winter crop).
  • (c) Gram – Also a Rabi crop, sown in winter and harvested in spring.
  • (d) Barley – Another Rabi crop that requires cooler temperatures.

question:
In which of the following ways were farmers encouraged to begin to use high yielding variety seeds ?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)
option_1: Farmers’ children were given free education in government colleges and universities.
option_2: Agricultural labourers were paid wages directly by the government.
option_3: Farmers were given monetary support in cash to cultivate food grains.
option_4: The government provided seeds and other inputs at prices lower than those prevailing in the market.
solution:
• The Green Revolution in India promoted the use of High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds to increase food grain production.
  • To encourage adoption, the government provided seeds, fertilizers, and other agricultural inputs at subsidized rates, i.e., lower than market prices.
  • This support made it economically viable for farmers to try new technologies.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Free education for farmers' children was not a strategy used for promoting HYV seeds.
  • (b) Wages for agricultural labourers were not directly paid by the government in this context.
  • (c) Direct cash support was not the primary method used; subsidies on inputs were more common.

Answer: (d) The government provided seeds and other inputs at prices lower than those prevailing in the market

question:
Which of the following is NOT an agro-based industry?

SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)
solution:
• An agro-based industry is one that uses agricultural products as raw materials. These industries process or manufacture goods derived from farming or plant/animal products.

Let’s review the options:

  • (a) Jute – ✅ Agro-based
    • Uses jute plant as raw material for producing bags, ropes, mats, etc.
  • (b) Fertiliser – ❌Not agro-based
    • Fertilisers are used in agriculture, but they are chemical-based and do not rely on agricultural raw materials.
    • Hence, it is an auxiliary to agriculture, not agro-based.
  • (c) Sugar – ✅ Agro-based
    • Made from sugarcane, a major agricultural crop.
  • (d) Edible oil – ✅ Agro-based
    • Extracted from oilseeds like mustard, groundnut, soybean, etc.

Answer: (b) Fertiliser

question:
Which of the following is NOT true with regard to the Green Revolution?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Cultivation became more intensive in nature.
option_2: In its second phase, there was a shift to from dry to wet (irrigated) cultivation in dry and semi-arid regions of India.
option_3: Cultivation became more extensive in nature.
option_4: There was change in the cropping pattern and types of crops grown in its second phase.
solution:
Let’s evaluate each statement about the Green Revolution:

  • (a) Cultivation became more intensive in nature – ✅True
    • With the introduction of HYV seeds, chemical fertilizers, and irrigation, farmers began cultivating the same land more intensively to increase productivity.
  • (b) In its second phase, there was a shift from dry to wet (irrigated) cultivation in dry and semi-arid regions – ✅True
    • The second phase (1980s onward) aimed to extend the benefits of irrigation and HYV crops to less developed, rain-fed areas.
  • (c) Cultivation became more extensive in nature – ❌Not true
    • Extensive cultivation refers to bringing new land under cultivation, but the Green Revolution focused on increasing output from existing land through intensification, not extensification.
  • (d) There was change in the cropping pattern and types of crops grown in its second phase – ✅True
    • The second phase introduced crop diversification and brought crops like pulses, oilseeds, and millets into focus.

Answer: (c) Cultivation became more extensive in nature

question:
Which crops are benefitted from the temperate cyclones arising from the Mediterranean Sea that cause rainfall in Punjab?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift- 1)
solution:
• Temperate cyclones originating from the Mediterranean Sea travel eastward and bring winter rainfall to northwestern India, especially Punjab, Haryana, and western Uttar Pradesh.
  • This rainfall occurs during the Rabi season (mainly from December to March) and is extremely beneficial for Rabi crops, especially wheat and barley.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Cash crops – This is a general category and not specific to season (can be Rabi or Kharif).
  • (b) Kharif crops – These are sown in the monsoon (June–October), so they do not benefit from winter rainfall.
  • (d) Zaid crops – These are grown in the short summer season between Rabi and Kharif, and are not impacted by Mediterranean rainfall.

Answer: (c) Rabi crops

question:
In July 1968, Indira Gandhi, the then Prime Minister of India, officially recorded impressive strides of the Green Revolution in agriculture by releasing a special stamp entitled _________ .

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
solution:
• In July 1968, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi commemorated the early success of the Green Revolution in India by releasing a special postage stamp.
  • This stamp was titled "Wheat Revolution", recognizing the dramatic increase in wheat production due to the use of High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds, fertilizers, and modern techniques.
  • The term “Wheat Revolution” was used instead of “Green Revolution” to highlight the crop-specific success during the initial phase.

Answer: (a) Wheat Revolution

question:
Which of the following reasons can be attributed to the excessive pressure on agricultural land in India?

a) Right of inheritance

b) Size of unprofitable land holding

c) Division of land

d) Multiple cropping

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
option_1: Only a and b
option_2: b, c and d
option_3: a, c and d
option_4: a, b and c
solution:
The excessive pressure on agricultural land in India arises mainly due to the following:

  • (a) Right of inheritance – ✅
    • Land is divided among heirs, leading to fragmentation and smaller landholdings.
  • (b) Size of unprofitable land holding – ✅
    • Many holdings are too small to be economically viable, yet families continue farming on them due to lack of alternatives.
  • (c) Division of land – ✅
    • Continuous subdivision among generations leads to further pressure on land resources.
  • (d) Multiple cropping – ❌
    • This is actually a positive agricultural practice, aiming to increase productivity from the same piece of land. It does not increase land pressure, but optimizes its use.

Hence, only a, b, and c are correct.

Answer: (d) a, b and c

question:
Which of the following countries is related with high yielding variety seeds that are used as part of Green Revolution policies in India?

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The High Yielding Variety (HYV) seeds, which played a central role in India’s Green Revolution, were primarily developed in Mexico.
  • These wheat varieties were a result of research led by Dr. Norman Borlaug, often referred to as the "Father of the Green Revolution."
  • The Mexican dwarf wheat varieties were introduced in India in the 1960s, and they significantly increased wheat productivity in states like Punjab and Haryana.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • (a) Russia – Not involved in HYV seed development for India.
  • (c) China – Had its own agricultural reforms, but not related to HYV seeds used in India.
  • (d) The US – Although Dr. Borlaug was American, the seeds were developed in Mexico.
